TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans. Did the Prime Minister tell you and other senior ministers that Jim McGinty, the Western Australian Labor leader, had told him six months ago that Carmen Lawrence's version of events in the Easton affair was wrong and that former Western Australian ministers would be compelled to tell the truth about the matter if subpoenaed by the Marks royal commission, or was he so willing to hide from the truth that he wasn't even prepared to confide in his own cabinet colleagues? Isn't this just another demonstration of the fact that Carmen Lawrence has been damned and found guilty of lying on the evidence of her own colleagues, or do you believe it is Jim McGinty who is the liar?

—I have not had an opportunity to check this morning with the Prime Minister as to whether any such conversation took place. But even if it did in the terms which are reported, that takes away nothing from the position that the Prime Minister and others of us in the government have adopted from the outset so far as this matter is concerned. I note that Mr McGinty is reported as having said that he told Mr Keating he was not doubting Carmen Lawrence's honesty; what he was doubting was her recollection. And that, of course, is what has been in issue from the outset.

PARA.TAB: What we have had in this whole proceeding is an extraordinary exercise flawed in its conception and poisoned at source, given the nature of the enterprise on which the Western Australian government was embarked: an utterly unprecedented use and misuse of executive investigative power—not the power of the courts but the power of the executive arm of government, a process that was utterly flawed in its conduct, poisoned in its conduct, by the bizarre and often farcical way in which the proceedings unfolded under the chairmanship of the royal commissioner, and a proceeding which was manifestly flawed in the terms in which the findings were detailed and described.

We, under those circumstances, taking that view, as so many people have done who have looked objectively at this whole course of events, find absolutely no reason in any way, shape or form to resile from the position we have taken, which is to believe throughout in Carmen Lawrence's veracity, to believe that this was an issue about competing recollections and to acknowledge that recollections can differ. It is not a matter of weighing bags of wheat or chaff on one side of the scale versus another side and saying, `Because there are more recollections this way than there are the other way, therefore, there must be some compelling reason for accepting the majority view.' It is a matter of taking into account all the circumstances of the matter and making an objective judgment accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —But, you see, he said—

—It does not matter who said what. The truth of the matter is that this has been a poisoned exercise from the outset—poisoned in its conception and poisoned in its conduct—and flawed in its findings; and we have no reason whatsoever to change our view of it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to recent statements which he and the Prime Minister have made about the government's vision for an increasingly inclusive and fair multicultural society in the 21st century and the importance of our non-discriminatory migration policy in its development. In this context, can the minister inform the Senate of the background to the abolition of the white Australia policy, when it was abolished and by whom?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Collins for this question. It goes to a policy which I have often described as our greatest mistake as a nation. The question you raise is one that needs to be addressed because it is important for us to clear up the question of history so that we do not repeat it and so that we can build for the future.

PARA.TAB: When we talk about the white Australia policy, we talk about a policy which took us 73 years to abolish—a policy which was in place at Federation. In terms of outlining the events until the abolition, let me make it clear that the policy was abolished by the Whitlam government in 1973. In March 1968, for instance, while in opposition, Gough Whitlam stated that under a Labor government `if a man or a woman has the skills which are welcome in Australia, the last thing we should have in mind is what race he or she is'. In June 1971, at the national ALP conference in Hobart, he promised a migration program based on a points system where matters such as race would be irrelevant. In 1972, as soon as he took over government, his minister, Al Grassby, moved to effect those changes, telling a reporter from the New York Times that he had given instructions that race was to be disregarded when applications from prospective migrants were considered. His words were—and I am pleased he used these:

ANSWER.PARA: In future, people will be treated for what they are, not on their complexion or the shape of their nose. People from Asia, New Guinea, from anywhere, will be admitted as Australian immigrants as long as they fit into the Australian scene. Colour will not count.

He acted in January 1973 to change migration policy and in fact changed the Citizenship Act to take out elements of explicit discrimination. That is how it happened. There were some minor changes in the 15 years beforehand and they need to be placed on the record.

PARA.TAB: In 1956, under the Liberal-Country Party coalition, some minor concessions were made. They were made, as Herbert London writes in his book Non-White Immigration—The White Australia Policy, because the government did not know what to do with non-European war refugees, particularly those from communist China, and war brides. In 1966, 10 years later, under the Holt government, some more minor and restrictive changes were introduced. They followed criticism by Gough Whitlam of racial discrimination in immigration policy, particularly affecting the deportation of a five-year-old Indian girl by the name of Prasad and the refusal to allow a Filipino accountant with two university degrees to migrate to Australia.

In 1966, there was some codification of expressions—two new restrictive minor categories—and they reduced from 15 years to five years the residence requirement for naturalisation of non-European residents, still much longer than Europeans. There was not a change of policy at that stage, nor was there an intention to. Mr Opperman, the then minister, made it clear that the government was not departing from `the fundamental principles, and the basic aim of preserving a homogenous population will be maintained'.

Mr Holt made it clear when he said on television that the review `did not mean fundamentals of the restricted policy would be changed'. The evidence is quite damming. In 1967, and after these changes, out of a migration program involving 140,000 people, 197 were non-European. You claim that was a change. There was no assisted passage for non-Europeans and the immigration department was carved up on racial grounds. There was a UK section, a European section, a mixed raced section and a non-European section.

Even in 1971, out of 155,000 migrants only 1,800 were allowed to sneak in from non-European bases. We saw during the 1972 campaign, when Whitlam was to take over government, people like Robert Askin claiming that Labor would `flood the country with black people'. Sir William McMahon, the then Prime Minister, warned that Labor's immigration policy would create a multi-racial society in Australia and ruin its European character.

—I will tell you in a second.

—You are going to tell us in a second, are you? Under the standing orders the minister is responsible for answering questions relating to public affairs and that presumably means contemporary matters. Mr President, I ask you to make a ruling in that regard.

I have obviously run out of time. If I am asked a supplementary question I will address the second part. —I will start once again by referring to an important article on immigration reform by Ken Rivett. When summarising the 1972 changes he made it very clear that there was no policy change to that time. It is important because there is a degree of revisionism going on. Mr Howard and Senator Short are running around the electorate spreading disinformation about the impact of the government's policy changes. They are claiming that the government abolished the white Australia policy.

PARA.TAB: That is not the truth. Any historian will tell you that Al Grassby and Gough Whitlam changed the white Australia policy. Any historian will tell you that what Senator Short and Mr Howard are on about is dissembling the facts. They think that they can con the electorate by telling lies on this particular issue. Mr Gear and Mr Keating both confidently predicted an increase to GDP of $25 billion and benefits to consumers of $1,500 a household. I ask: does the government now consider that the Industry Commission's estimates of these big gains of competition policy were hopelessly wrong and overstated?

—No. The Industry Commission's estimates are the Industry Commission's estimates. If one looks at the reasoning by which the Industry Commission brought about those estimates, they can see the basis for them. I am not entirely sure what Mr Gear may have said that causes you to ask me this question, but he has sort of distanced himself from what the Industry Commission has said.

PARA.TAB: What is clear about competition policy is that it does require the full weight of competition policy to be properly implemented. That can be done by the federal government, but it most importantly needs to be done at the state government level—and it needs to be done, I might add, against a background of political certainty.

What is appropriate to observe at this point is the remarks of my colleague Senator Bob Collins about the uncertainty of the opposition when it comes to competition policy and the division within the ranks of the opposition, between the National Party and the Liberal Party, in terms of their commitment to competition policy. Because of that division and confusion, because of the conflict on the other side, there is no certainty that those gains estimated by the Industry Commission of $1,500 per household could be achieved if the coalition were in government, because there is no certainty that the coalition would provide the strength and the determination to follow through on the implementation of competition policy.

It may be in that context that Mr Gear was remarking. It may be in some other context that I do not have information about at the moment. But the Industry Commission's estimates were, as I recall, the potential gains for Australia, and the potential related to the full implementation of their policy and not a partial or half-hearted one.

It is also true that competition policy is one of the great micro-economic reforms pushed by this government. The $25 billion gain to GDP is a gain achieved by making Australia a more efficient economy, thus enabling our goods to be landed in foreign markets at cheaper prices and win a greater share, creating growth in Australian industry and jobs for Australians. That is what our competition policy is about. That is why there is a figure in terms of household gains.

I do not have the full text of what Mr Gear may or may not have said. The bottom line is that the Industry Commission has made those estimates. It is a reputable independent authority and is in a position to make those estimates. I have nothing before me to indicate that we should in any way distance ourselves from or undercut the potential gains figured into the equation by the Industry Commission.
They seem to be reasonable estimates, given that the proposals for competition reform are properly introduced. That is the province of the states.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I will send you the full text. Mr Gear said at the launch of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, `I don't particularly endorse the precise numbers.' He went on to say, `But they give us an indication of the extent.' Isn't it your tactic to rely on the Industry Commission as a kind of propaganda shock troop to come in here and soften us up for the application of yet another theory? Hasn't it gone wrong this time? Didn't you rely on this to get the states to come to the table on the competition policy reform agreement? Weren't you dishonest in relying on this, when others have said it has been overstated to the tune of 90 per cent, that is, $21 billion?

—Now that you have given me the fuller text of what Mr Gear said, it seems to me that what he said is an appropriate observation for a minister to make, given that those estimates are always dependent on the full application of competition policy. If that is in the hands of some of the states that may not occur. He may have been making that point. I have not read the full text of his speech.

PARA.TAB: The Industry Commission is a reputable independent authority. It exists to shine a searching light of economic and fiscal rectitude on the Australian economy. We are a government that welcomes that type of scrutiny and that type of independent analysis. We are not afraid of it. We won't close it down for the reason that its findings might be uncomfortable. We reserve the right, as a government, in the face of those findings, to make appropriate decisions for the Australian community. That involves a consideration of the economic matters that the Industry Commission has referred to. It also involves social and other considerations. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Ray, representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Given the ACTU has claimed the determination by the Industrial Relations Commission a victory for the trade union movement, can you explain why the workers at Weipa are still out on strike and why the CFMEU is threatening an all out strike in the coal industry which is predicted to last for months? Does your government support this continuation of work bans? Don't these disputes reveal that the union movement is out of control? When is your government going to start to show some national leadership?

—The Industrial Relations Commission hearing earlier this week was about the broad and general principles. It brought about a greater degree of negotiation between the company and the union. The Industrial Relations Commission tried to establish that there was nothing wrong with individual contracts but that if used as a pure and simple lever against collective bargaining and if there was no equal pay for equal work that was wrong in principle.

PARA.TAB: However, there still remain matters to be resolved between the work force, represented in part by collective leadership, and by the employer. They are not fully resolved yet. It is not for our government to say the way in which it should be resolved.
Our first and main task was to see that the dispute did not spread and that innocent third parties were not affected by the dispute. That is where we showed the necessary leadership.

I did hear in the chamber last week the words of your ultimate leader that it was not necessary to take sides and intervene in every dispute and in every aspect of every dispute. That remains the case. The leadership of a government is to provide adequate legislation and to provide the framework in which some form of reconciliation can occur when these disputes emerge. That is what we have done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you support the continuation of work bans? That was my question. It has cost a couple of hundred million dollars already. Do you support it?

—It is simply not a fair question to ask whether I support this, that or the other. What I support is a resolution of the issues using the full array of what is provided by way of legislation and by way of encouragement.

—I ask the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories: in view of the most serious salinity crisis in Western Australia which presently affects 1.6 million hectares of state agricultural land, how does the minister respond to the Western Australian government's comment that its ability to tackle the problem is being hindered by a lack of federal government support? What is the federal government proposing to do? What commitment will the minister give to provide funding beyond the current inadequate levels?

—I react very cynically to any claims by the Western Australian government about the role of the Commonwealth in relation to the protection of our environment, and I think there is very good reason I can be so cynical. I think Senator Chamarette would be aware that Australia's strategy for the protection of our conservation of biodiversity has been a national strategy and a very important strategy.

PARA.TAB: But what is the state that has to date failed to sign up to that strategy and work with the Commonwealth and other states and territories? It is of course the state of Western Australia. What has been the last state in Australia to come on board with the National Environment Protection Council? It is the state of Western Australia. What is the state in Australia that is dragging the chain in relation to protection of our coasts in this country? It is in fact the state of Western Australia.

In so many other areas the characteristic approach of the Western Australian government has been to not work cooperatively with either the Commonwealth or other state and territory governments in this country. It has been traditional for the Western Australian government to take the view that it does not support the other governments at any level—be it state, territory or Commonwealth—to be uncooperative and to take the view that it is impossible for us to develop national strategies, but that is because of their blinkered ideological approach to these issues on the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except when they want money.

—That might be true, Senator Collins. I think the record is very clear in relation to the level of cooperation we have seen from the Western Australian government. Senator Chamarette, that is something that is also recognised even in some other conservative state jurisdictions in Australia. Any objective observer, in relation to the Western Australian government's record on environment protection, would say very clearly that the Western Australian government's record is very poor, that it is worse than any other state or territory in Australia and that it has deliberately determined an ideological position of not cooperating with the Commonwealth government and not cooperating with other levels of government in Australia to see environmental protection.

PARA.TAB: I do not accept any allegations from the Western Australian government, nor will I ever accept any criticism from the Western Australian government, in relation to salinity problems or any other environmental problems where this government—the Commonwealth government—has a strong record of national leadership and where we work and continue to work to encourage other governments to cooperate with and assist those governments to benefit from and protect the environment in this country. It has been Western Australia that has stood out against this approach over the past two years. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate that I have given a free kick to the Western Australian government from the environment minister but I still have not heard whether the federal government will commit any funds to this serious salinity crisis—in particular, with relevance to assisting in the geophysical mapping of the arid regions, community assistance to farm forestry, and reduction of raised water table problems to deal with irrigation salinity. Minister, you have not given any response that says what the federal government is doing in relation to the salinity crisis. I would appreciate it if we could get some indication of the government's willingness to take a role in that important problem.

—Mr President, as I have said on many occasions in this chamber, the Commonwealth government has shown leadership on this issue through, for example: the national landcare program, $110 million this year; in my own department, programs such as Save the Bush and One Billion Trees; and our programs in relation to ensuring river health in this country, such as our national strategy for rangeland management. This government has led this issue. It has been recalcitrance on the part of Western Australia to involve itself in this Commonwealth leadership on these sorts of issues.

PARA.TAB: You have seen what can be achieved—the Murray-Darling Basin initiative—when we get a level of cooperation between other states and other jurisdictions. It is achievable with cooperation, which is not forthcoming from Western Australia. (Time expired)

—Oh, was it! When I get the opportunity—

I know from my own information from the NFF that this story in the Financial Review is absolutely accurate.

PARA.TAB: The National Farmers Federation originally said, `No, we're not going to cop that,' and then there were several other conversations between Mr Howard's office and the NFF. Finally, there was an agreement that someone at the NFF would draft three questions for farmers in the room—and, Senator Boswell, I am amazed you have asked this—and the questions were given to Mr Howard the night before he spoke at the National Farmers Federation conference. I have to tell you the context of this. This is a constituency which they think is theirs. This is an organisation which they think supports them.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: we have now had the opportunity to hear an utterly irrelevant tirade. If he wants to explain why it is that Gary Gray could not address the substance of issues without descending to that gutter level, then we would be interested in hearing that. But it can't possibly be a reason for now talking about other matters on another day that have nothing to do with this question.
—I indicated at the outset that the question of relevance was in the question itself. I would have thought that the question was of dubious relevance, and I said that to the minister at the time.
—Exactly. I will conclude, Senator Alston, by saying this. If Mr Howard is so frightened to take a single question at a forum that he considers to be his natural constituency, then—
—Mr President, I take a point of order on the grounds that Senator Collins is misleading the Senate, because Mr Howard—
—It is not a point of order, Senator MacGibbon. That is not a point of order, Senator MacGibbon, and you know it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I happen to have discussed this with Mr Howard beforehand. I know the pressures he was under.
—Order! That is not a point of order. You have made your statement. It is not a point of order.

—I will conclude by saying this. If Mr Howard is frightened to take a single question from a constituency that he regards as his own, then Little Johnny does not possess the qualities to be a Prime Minister of this country.

—The minister conceded that the language was intemperate and that Mr Gary Gray was wrong. But the whole point of the question that I asked was: would he take the opportunity to apologise to the people that he represents as their minister, particularly to the women who were there—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not ALP women; they do find this language offensive. Would he apologise to these women who are not used to listening to this language?

—What I intend to do—and I have just said it—is speak to Gary and indicate that I was not pleased. Yes, he is a friend of mine and I thought it was an unprofessional lapse. But I think the person who needs to apologise is the Leader of the Opposition for indicating just how totally gutless he is and how totally unfit for high office he is.

—Mr President, on a point of order: could you explain to me how this answer is relevant to the question that I asked about an apology? I would be happy if you interpreted my question to be out of order, but would you please explain to me how the answer is relevant?

—I made the point earlier that the question was irrelevant in the first place. The question of relevance should have applied to the question itself. I invited the minister to answer it if he wanted to, and he did. He is entitled to be broad in what was a broad question.
—Mr President, regrettably I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Mr President, on a point of order: I heard Senator Collins reflect on John Howard by calling him `gutless'. I remind the Senate that I had to withdraw once for calling Senator Cook gutless. So I am asking you to get him to withdraw.
—Withdraw.
—Nobody could ever accuse me of being gutless, Senator Panizza. I withdraw.
—Mr President, I refer to your ruling earlier today that the mere mention of a name is the imputation of an incorrect motive. The mention of a `Lawrence' implies lying or amnesia—
—Of Arabia.

—Lawrence of Arabia or D.H. Lawrence or Bizet's Carmen. Mr President, if your ruling stands as it is, it means that we could call a `Bolkus' to mean a thief or something. This is the imputation of your ruling regarding the mention of a name—whether it be a person who is in this chamber or somebody totally unconnected with it. Murphy's law might apply. There are all sorts of implications. So, Mr President, I ask you to reconsider that ruling. I shall certainly put it in writing, but I ask you to consider it.
—Let me make the comment that rulings are always made in a context. You are fully aware of the context in which that ruling was made and of the way the name `Carmen' was being used.

—by leave—Mr President, I heard what you said in your ruling in respect of Minister Lawrence and Senator Macdonald. On both areas I respectfully suggest that you might reconsider that ruling. To coin a phrase, I do not think two wongs make a white on this particular occasion. I am just referring to Arthur Calwell's remark. I respectfully ask you to reconsider that ruling.
—Thank you for that comment. I will respond after having considered it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), to a question without notice asked by Senator Jacinta Collins this day, relating to the history of the restricted immigration White Australia policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite frankly, my coalition colleagues and I are sure the majority of Australians of all backgrounds are absolutely sick to death of the continual revisionist attempts by this government to rewrite the migration history of this nation, and particularly the history of the abolition of the white Australia policy.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that it was the coalition government of Prime Minister Harold Holt that took the decisions that effectively abolished the white Australian policy of 1966, although I freely and frankly accept, and always have accepted, that it was the Whitlam government that finally swept away its last vestiges. But the essential decisions were taken by coalition governments and, more specifically, the landmark, the watershed decisions, were taken by the Holt government of 1966.

I just want to retrace a little of the history of this whole subject, and I know that some of my colleagues will wish to do the same. It is a fact that the Chifley government's policy after the war was overwhelmingly British oriented and totally European. Its priorities were the UK, northern Europe and southern Europe. Non-Europeans were allowed to enter Australia on a temporary basis only. That white Australia policy had been the cornerstone of Labor's immigration policy since, I think, 1906. An example of the strength of feeling still emanating from that policy in those early postwar years was Labor's refusal—the Chifley government's refusal—in the late 1940s to allow Australian ex-servicemen located in Japan to bring their Japanese wives to Australia.

In 1949, the Chifley government was responsible for the passage of the War-time Refugees Removal Bill, the purpose of which was to expel some 9,000 Asians who were among those evacuated to Australia during the war and who, having married Australians, established businesses, or settled into employment, refused to leave after the war had ended. In 1949, one of the very first actions of the incoming Menzies government was to allow those Asians to stay in Australia.

It is true that both Menzies and his immigration minister, Mr Holt, in 1950, like Calwell and Chifley before them, emphasised the desire for the immigration program to be predominantly oriented towards the British and Irish; it was a pretty bipartisan approach in those days. But Menzies also, even that far back, laid great stress on a broader scenario. In his address to the 1950 citizenship convention, the first one to be held after he was elected to government, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We must strike down at its very inception the rather insular tendency that exists in the minds of some persons to object to a man because of his race or his religion . . . Prejudice against a migrant because of race or origin is not a sign of pride but a sign of stupidity . . .
Indeed, he said:
(The British) of all people are the most mixed . . . the product of wave after wave of peoples from the caucasus westward.

Right from the outset of the Menzies government and during ensuing coalition governments, there was that importance and stress on non-discrimination on the basis of race, religion, ethnicity and all those things. That was reflected in a series of decisions in the 1950s and 1960s, leading up to the landmark decisions, which implemented major changes, that were made by the Holt government with its then immigration minister, `Oppy'—Hubert Opperman—in March 1966.

PARA.TAB: The coalition's record, in terms of non-discrimination and a progressive set of policies right through its history in government to abolish discrimination in the area of migration in this country, is unsurpassed by any political party in Australia's history. I take the greatest exception to these continuing revisionist attempts by the Labor Party opposite to rewrite the truth of this country's history. The fact is that Labor was dragged along, screaming, by coalition parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it extraordinary that the honourable senator (Senator Jacinta Collins) on the other side should ask a dorothy dixer, inviting the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) to rewrite the history of Australia's immigration policy. As Senator Short has quite correctly said here in this place, the history of the white Australia policy is that that policy received its death-knell under the Holt coalition government.

PARA.TAB: The facts are these. It was the Labor Party that introduced the white Australia policy; it was the Labor Party that refined the white Australia policy to its most bigoted and most extreme form; and it was the Labor Party, with Mr Calwell as immigration minister, that introduced the War-time Refugees Removal Bill that sought to expel people from this country—people who were war veterans and who had served this country—purely because of their race.

What could be more bigoted than that—expelling people who had served this country during a time of war on the basis that they were Asian? That is what that 1949 election was all about. That was one of the key issues in that election and that was why Labor lost. But it goes on because the people on the other side would like us to believe that they were the ones who abolished the white Australia policy, that they were the ones who opened the door to the rest of the world. The door was opened to the rest of the world by the coalition under the Colombo Plan. We were the first people to actually invite people from Asian nations to come and study here. We were the first people to internationalise—

TALK.START.PARA: —Colombo.

—Exactly—the Colombo Plan. We were the first people to internationalise this country's society. Yet the Labor Party would have us believe they did it. I want to expose the truth about the Labor Party's concern for people of Asian origin after 1972. You see, they would have us believe that Al Grassby abolished the white Australia policy.

PARA.TAB: The truth is—and I want all the honourable senators on the other side to hear this—in 1974, after the Vietnam war had concluded for Australia, there were hundreds of people in that country—some of whom had served at our embassy, others who had served with our armed forces—who sought entry to Australia because the tide of communism was sweeping down Vietnam and they knew that they were branded as collaborators with Australia. How many people from Vietnam were allowed into this country by the Whitlam Labor government? Was it 200—no. Was it 100—no. It was 76.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.
—It is disgraceful. That is the total number of Vietnamese the Labor Party took in 1974. The hundreds of others who had served Australia—
—In one year?

—In one year, yes. But, Senator Collins, it was the one year in which we pulled out of Vietnam leaving hundreds of people behind who had served with our armed forces, who had served in our embassy and had been loyal friends of Australia. What happened to those hundreds of people? They were arrested; they were tortured; they were persecuted; and many of them were killed. That is the Labor Party's record on Asian immigration after 1972. They are the facts, Senator Jacinta Collins. If you do not like them, I am very sorry but that is the truth. That is how the Labor Party turned its back on its friends in 1974.

PARA.TAB: Just before then, we still had Mr Calwell in 1971 asking questions about the composition of migrants following the decision by Mr Opperman to effectively abolish the white Australia policy. For example, on 19 August 1971 Mr Calwell wanted to know the number of people who had arrived in Australia in 1967-68, 1968-69 and 1969-70. He wanted the figures in tabular form based on `pure blood' and `mixed blood' people from each Asian and African country—pure blood and mix blood people from each Asian and African country. That is the extent of the concern and regard for a multicultural country that we had under the Labor Party.

The people on the other side inherited the most racist, political policy ever in this country. They should hang their heads in shame. The suggestion that the Labor Party had abolished the white Australia policy and was the friend of the Asian community in this country is quite clearly disgraceful, dishonest and dastardly. I believe all Australians should condemn the government for the way in which it has so wilfully misled the people and the Senate today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was tempted to leave the other two parties entirely to their squabble as to who was whiter than white, so to speak, in the past. However, what matters is what happens now and what happens in the future. I would like to challenge both parties to ensure that ethnic people in Australia now and in the future have equal opportunity; that we provide English language classes free and in an accessible location; that we recognise professional qualifications and that we do not impose quotas on professional qualifications; and that we ensure that ethnic people have adequate and effective information on our political process and are able to participate in our political process, including participation in the Australian parliament and in the state parliaments.That is what matters, rather than this squabble as to who did what first or last in the past. I commend all senators to consider what we do in the future to create a tolerant, all-inclusive and cohesive multicultural society in Australia.

—I endorse what Senator Spindler has said. Again, he has made quite a magnificent contribution in this chamber. I think he has brought all of us to the realisation that it is the future that counts. I think that in the past, people from all political viewpoints have contributed in a great way to the sort of society we now have. I include in that—and it is for this reason I have got to my feet—Arthur Calwell, who began the trend we have followed since the Second World War. He was our first immigration minister and an outstanding one.

PARA.TAB: Senator Harradine quoted a phrase which I am sure he did not intend to be in any way hurtful. It was a phrase that has become quite famous: `Two wongs don't make a white'. That phrase is attributed to Arthur Calwell on a racist basis. I know it has upset his family for a long while. His daughter, Mary Elizabeth Calwell, has often raised that issue. I take this opportunity to put in context what she tells me about that, and which I accept. What happened was that there was a Mr White at that time who was the member for Balaclava, a seat which has now become the seat of Goldstein.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good member.
—Yes, I see Senator Kemp, who knows the seat of Goldstein.
—A good local member.

—Even though he may be a good local member, Senator Kemp, his brother who is in the Senate is even better, they tell me. In any event, I am making a serious point. I take this opportunity to correct that injustice to a great Australian and a great migration minister. He was not a racist in the sense in which that word is used; he was a person who had great friends amongst the Chinese community. In fact, he could speak Mandarin. He was married to a woman from Ireland. It just goes to show how tolerant he was. He was married to someone from Ireland; I sit next to someone from Ireland. That proves how unracist we are.

PARA.TAB: Can I vindicate at this point the name of Arthur Calwell, the then member for Melbourne, and indicate that at no stage was he racist. That comment has been taken completely out of context—the context being that he was using the member for Balaclava, Mr White, as a subject for the comment he made. He was not using the word `white' in the sense that that word is used in the term `white Australia policy'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Cooney for his comments. I make it perfectly clear that I had no intention whatsoever of denigrating Arthur Calwell. In fact, on many occasions I have defended Arthur Calwell with respect to immigration. The economic engine that drove the economic development years of the 1950s and 1960s resulted from a lot of the work of Arthur Calwell in this area of immigration. I am sorry because it was merely a flippant remark and was completely out of context. I regret that.
—Can I put on the record that I accept absolutely what you are saying.

—Thank you very much, Senator Cooney. I come to the point that Senator Spindler made. I think we have to look at the situation here and now. I think it was an appropriate question for Senator Jacinta Collins to ask. I do not know whether Senator Collins or the rest of us expected the response that we got from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus). The minister was asked a question and he gave us a response.

PARA.TAB: I take this opportunity to raise a matter which is of grave concern. This issue affects people here and now. It affects our standing as a country that prides itself on its human rights record and on its attitudes to justice. I refer particularly to the repatriation—if that is the correct word—of a number of Sino-Vietnamese who have been sent back to China even though they were seeking refuge from China. Because of the operation of the safe third country legislation which passed this parliament, against my wishes, these people have been sent back to the PRC. They are Vietnamese who fled Vietnam some years ago and are now fleeing China.

I believe that the hands and feet of the immigration officers are tied in this regard. What I am concerned about—and this emerged from our consideration of estimates in the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee—is the fact that the federal government paid for a group of PRC officials to go and interview these people whilst they were in detention in Australia.

Just imagine how you would feel if you had fled from the PRC and then were interrogated by PRC officials whilst you were in detention in Australia. Is that a fair and just thing to do. It might be said that this method is used to ensure that these people are relocated in China in better circumstances than they previously had. I doubt that very much. The fact is that there is no constant monitoring.

The better question to have asked the minister would have been: will Australia ensure that there is constant monitoring of these people sent back to the PRC to ensure that they are not victimised and are cared for? It concerns me considerably that that will not happen. I appeal to the minister and the government to set aside money so that we can—leave aside the UNHCR because it does not do this in general terms—monitor the welfare of these people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is a tragedy when the question of immigration and previous migration policies of this country become the topic for cheap political point scoring and gratuitous exercises such as we have just witnessed in question time today. It was undoubtedly a set-up question to allow the minister to rewrite some Australian history.

PARA.TAB: The people such as Arthur Calwell that Senator Cooney tried to defend were undoubtedly a product of their time. But I would challenge Senator Cooney, for example, to put into context these three comments attributed to and made by Arthur Calwell. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Japanese women should not be allowed to pollute our shores.
Another one:

I say to Senator Cooney: try to put that into context. What I have to say to this Senate is that, unfortunately, Arthur Calwell was a product of his time—and a lot of people, unfortunately, held those views within Australia—just as much as the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is a product of his time and his upbringing within the trade union movement. In his maiden speech on 17 March 1970, he said this:
It is time we considered the enormous cost of bringing migrants to this country . . . After all, the best migrant is the infant Australian.

How does that make Senator McKiernan feel? How does that make me feel? How does that make every immigrant in this country feel? They are the words of our Prime Minister. He has never recanted them; he has never apologised for them, yet the Australian Labor Party has the absolute audacity to try to set up a dorothy dixer during question time to take a free shot at the Liberal Party.

PARA.TAB: The question of migration, the question of our multicultural society, is a lot more serious than cheap political point scoring. That is why, with respect, on the Racial Hatred Bill—now the Racial Hatred Act—the community was so divided, because Senator Bolkus in particular and the Labor government were motivated by one thing and one thing alone: cheap politics. They were not interested in getting a consensus, of working with the people of Australia, of working with all the immigrant groups within Australia. At the end of the Racial Hatred Bill, you had these ethnic organisations supporting the legislation and another bucket full of ethnic organisations opposing the legislation. Is that the sort of country we are trying to develop? Is that the sort of social fabric that we want?

Just so it is not misinterpreted as to why I quoted Arthur Calwell and the Prime Minister, let me say that there has been a deliberate campaign of misinformation by the Labor Party trying to paint the Liberal Party as somehow being racist, anti-immigration and all those sorts of things. Unfortunately, our friends in the media often write along those lines, because the spin doctors in the National Media Liaison Service and the Ministerial Media Group always pick out phrases from Liberal ministers and Liberal people from the 1950s and do not tell the media about the sorts of quotes that I have just given this parliament from Arthur Calwell and Prime Minister Keating.

All I have sought to do is even up the ledger and provide some information so that the people of Australia can see that that was an era of the past, shared in general terms by both sides of politics. We are now in a new and, might I dare say, a more enlightened era in which there is the basis for a great degree of consensus. The only people wanting to attack that newfound consensus are the likes of Senator Bolkus who think that they can make cheap politics out of this very important issue. I plead with them to desist.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to thank Senator Spindler and Senator Harradine for their comments today. Picking up on the comments made by Senator O'Chee in relation to my supposed dorothy dixer, I must say that his continued insults during these debates do him no benefit at all.

PARA.TAB: I did seek to relate my question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) to the current situation. I want to address some of the comments of opposition speakers. Senator Short seemed to indicate that, yes, we did have these unfortunate views in the 1940s and 1950s and they were from both parties. That is definitely the case. But what the Labor Party can say quite clearly and unequivocally is that under Whitlam in the 1970s we faced up to and rectified our past with respect to those types of policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about 1966?

—In 1966 they supposedly made some essential decisions, according to Senator Short, but they did not make the essential attitudinal changes that were required of them. Let me refer to some of the debate that occurred in the 1970s. In the last week of the 1972 campaign, New South Wales Premier Askin, on the floor of the New South Wales parliament, accused the Labor Party of wanting to flood the country with black people. Prime Minister McMahon warned that Labor's immigration policy would create a multi-racial society in Australia and erode its European character.

PARA.TAB: Nothing changed after the Whitlam victory. During debate on Grassby's proposed changes to the Australian Citizenship Act in May 1973 the opposition's Dr Forbes, previous immigration minister, asked the parliament: `What is wrong with treating people differently, people who are differently placed? What is wrong with discrimination when there are valid overwhelming reasons to discriminate? People from Britain historically have been treated differently because they integrate more quickly into the Australian community than any other national group.'

Labor's policies seek to assist all groups to integrate into Australian society. We do not propose that we should discriminate or be selective about which groups we seek to make part of our national character. That is the current situation. That is the future that we want. That is the future that we want to encourage.

Quite clearly, in the 1970s the Labor Party recanted those views that have been expressed in the past. We faced up to our past clearly and openly. The challenge for the opposition is that they need to clearly demonstrate that they will do the same. That is the policy they lack at the moment. That is the leadership that the Australian public is looking for and that is what they are not finding with the opposition.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The summary read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This Determination made on 19 July 1995, provided for the remuneration and allowances for the Director of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority.

Clause 1 provided for salary of $122,400 per annum, to be reduced by the amount of any additional superannuation contributions payable by the CASA in accordance with superannuation arrangements approved by the Minister for Finance.

Clause 2 provided for performance based remuneration of up to $20,000 payable annually, assessed by the Board of the CASA in accordance with Guidelines advised by the Remuneration Tribunal from time to time.
Clause 3 provided for additional remuneration of $50,000 per annum, clause 4 for travelling allowance and clause 5 for annual leave loading.

The Committee was concerned that the subdelegations in clauses 1 and 2 may have been subdelegations of legislative rather than administrative power and therefore invalid in the absence of express enabling authority in the parent Act or some other Act. On 1 September 1995 the Committee accordingly wrote to the Hon Laurie Brereton MP, Minister for Industrial Relations. On 18 October 1995 the Minister advised that the discretion given to the CASA in clause 1 could be characterised as a valid delegation of administrative power and that it was a matter of judgement whether the guidelines in clause 2 could be categorised in the same way. The Minister advised that the Department had sought legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department and that if necessary the Minister would take up with the Remuneration Tribunal appropriate amendment of the Determination.

The Committee has now been provided with the Attorney-General's Department advice. In respect of clause 1, the advice was that, while it was arguable that the subdelegation was invalid, the provision was not inconsistent with the power of the Tribunal to determine remuneration. Clause 2, however, purported to allow CASA to determine the level of remuneration of the Director and that clause was therefore invalid in its entirety.

Remuneration Tribunal Determination No 12 of 1995 was made under the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973, which includes a number of possibly unique provisions relating to parliamentary scrutiny of delegated legislation. One such provision is s.7(7), which provides that a Determination must be tabled within 15 sitting days of being received by the Minister from the Tribunal and not, as is usual, within 15 sitting days of being made. The Minister has, however, undertaken to amend the Act as soon as practicable to impose a time limit for sending Determinations to the Minister, taking into account the debate on the Legislative Instruments Bill 1994. The Committee is grateful for this helpful undertaking. Another possibly unique provision is s.7(8), which provides that Determinations may be disallowed only within 15 sitting days of tabling, instead of the more usual 15 sitting days of a notice given within that period. On behalf of the Committee I will write to the Minister suggesting that this provision could also be amended, again subject to the Legislative Instruments Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: STUDENT AND YOUTH ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT (YOUTH TRAINING ALLOWANCE) BILL No.2 1995

This bill will make changes to the Youth Training Allowance provisions of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973. Late last year these provisions were incorporated into part 8 of the act and modelled on those for job search allowance found in the Social Security Act 1991. As the Youth Training Allowance and job search allowance are closely aligned it is important that any changes to one are mirrored in the other, and commence at or about the same time.

The Youth Training Allowance is just one part of the Youth Training Initiative. To those leaving school early, the Youth Training Initiative offers more than an income support payment. It offers case management, training and jobs. Young people who leave school at the end of the school year can be eligible for this assistance, not six months or a year down the track, but at around the same time as their former classmates are beginning a new year of school.
Young people now realise that if they want to have a good well paid job they need to stay on at school, look for an apprenticeship or a traineeship, or pursue further vocational training.

Jobs that are full-time, well paid and stable increasingly require education, training and skills. If we are to help early school leavers who are unemployed we need to give them the training and skills that will the open doors to full-time quality jobs. That is what the Youth Training Initiative aims to do and that is why we pay 15 to 17 year olds Youth Training Allowance rather than job search allowance.

Several of the amendments that are proposed in this bill will contribute directly to the main aim of the Youth Training Initiative—improving the job prospects of early school leavers. The remaining amendments will foster efficient administration of the Youth Training Allowance by keeping it aligned with the common provisions of the Social Security Act 1991.

The amendments in Schedule 1 close a minor loophole in the calculation of Youth Training Allowance for those who receive a periodic compensation payment paid as a lump sum. The treatment of compensation payments to a couple where one member of the couple receives Youth Training Allowance and the other a benefit under the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 is also amended to ensure consistency across commonwealth income support measures.

The amendments in Schedule 2 have two objectives. The first is to allow 15 year olds who are assessed as `independent' to qualify for YTA immediately, even if they do not meet the workforce requirements. Currently these people can only be paid special benefit. The second objective is to allow 15 year olds who have a workforce history, and who live with parents who are in receipt of commonwealth income support, to qualify immediately for Youth Training Allowance.

The amendments in Schedule 3 will allow Youth Training Allowance overpayments to be offset against any student assistance payments, such as austudy, which a person may subsequently be entitled to receive. This will lead to a more consistent debt management function.

The amendments in Schedule 4 will mean that part of a waiting period served for Youth Training Allowance or sickness allowance will be transferable should a client move from one to the other during the waiting period. It is possible at the moment for a client to apply for one allowance, begin to serve a waiting period, claim the other allowance, and then be required to serve a second waiting period.

Schedule 5 enhances the provisions dealing with the waiver and recoverability of debts. The amendments will permit partial waiver of a debt in certain circumstances, as well as clarifying when it is more cost effective to waive some smaller debts. The amendments will allow for more flexible negotiated settlements to avoid unnecessary and costly administrative appeals. They also give a mechanism for considering an upfront part-payment to quit a debt based on commercial considerations. The amendments will permit the non-recovery of a debt where there are special circumstances that make recovery inequitable. Furthermore, the amendments will allow debts subject to administrative appeals tribunal proceedings to be settled in the same manner as an `out of court' settlement of a matter before a civil court.

Schedule 6 makes some minor clarifications regarding the time a client has to nominate a bank account once approval of Youth Training Allowance is made, and what allowance might be backpaid if the client does not nominate an account within a prescribed time.

The amendments in Schedule 7 will increase by $5 a fortnight the amount of rent that must be paid before rent assistance may be offered. It also increases by $5 a fortnight the maximum amount of rent assistance that may be paid to a family. These changes will improve the targeting and effectiveness of rent assistance.
The amendments in Schedule 8 make minor technical corrections to the principal act. Among these is a clarification of the definition of `protected information.'
I commend the bill to the Senate.
STUDENT AND YOUTH ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT (YOUTH TRAINING ALLOWANCE) (No.3) BILL 1995

This bill will make changes to the Youth Training Allowance provisions of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 that are found in part 8 of the act. These were incorporated into the Student and Youth Assistance Act late last year and modelled on the job search allowance provisions contained in the Social Security Act 1991. As the Youth Training Allowance and job search allowance are closely aligned it is important that any changes to one are mirrored in the other, and commence at or about the same time.
These amendments follow amendments proposed to the Social Security Act 1991 by the Social Security And Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Budget Measures) Bill 1995.

The Youth Training Allowance is just one part of the Youth Training Initiative. To early school leavers this initiative offers more than just an income support payment, it offers case management, training and jobs. Case management at 13 weeks makes sure that early school leavers are not lost in the crowd. A young person's case manager works with them individually to map a pathway out of unemployment. Case managers can immediately offer a wide range of training, education and work experience options.

Early access to training, education and work experience opportunities is vital for early school leavers. Young people who enter the labour market without post-secondary qualifications or work experience find it difficult to get full-time permanent jobs. Skills, qualifications and experience are more important now than at any time in the past. The Youth Training Initiative offers a way out of the no job, no experience, no qualifications trap.

This initiative is an active response to youth unemployment. Income support should not aim to treat the symptoms of unemployment, it should work to tackle the causes. This bill will make sure that the income support component of the Youth Training Initiative, the Youth Training Allowance, operates smoothly as part of an integrated package of assistance.

The amendments in Schedule 1 mirror amendments proposed to the Social Security Act 1991. They are intended primarily to ensure the consistency of commonwealth income support measures and prevent anomalies arising between income support payments. These amendments simplify the rules applying to financial investments. At present there are many different and complex rules for calculating the income from financial investments. These amendments will mean that those rules will no longer apply and financial investments will be assessed under one set of simple rules.

The amendment in Schedule 2 will provide for unemployed clients who are temporarily unable to work because of illness or injury to remain in receipt of Youth Training Allowance, instead of being required to transfer to sickness allowance. By remaining on Youth Training Allowance they will continue to access eligibility for the full range of assistance available to the unemployed. This access will encourage them to pursue education or training activities as they recover.

The amendments in Schedule 3 make changes to the earnings credit scheme. This scheme operates to provide an incentive for a person to undertake part-time or casual employment. When the ordinary income test is applied for the purposes of calculating a person's fortnightly rate of a benefit, short periods of remunerative work could have the effect of reducing the person's rate of benefit.

Currently, recipients of Youth Training Allowance can accrue an earnings credit from which they can offset earnings for remunerative work before the income test is applied. A person may offset an amount of earnings up to the person's earnings credit balance, which is a maximum of $500. Earnings credits are not accessible if the person's fortnightly rate of ordinary income exceeds an amount that reduces the rate of the person's assistance to nil. The proposed amendments will allow a person to access earnings credit notwithstanding that the person's ordinary income amount would, if the income test were applied, reduce the rate of the assistance to nil. Further adjustments to the application of earnings credits are also made.

Amendments to the Social Security Act 1991 amalgamate the job search allowance (JSA) and newstart allowance (NSA) into one payment type called newstart allowance. The amendments in Schedule 4 are consequential amendments arising from this change.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: DEVELOPMENT ALLOWANCE AUTHORITY AMENDMENT BILL 1995
This bill amends the Development Allowance Authority Act 1992 (the principal act).

The primary purpose of the bill is to amend the principal act to remove certain restrictions on the restructuring of ownership of projects eligible for the Development Allowance so that a more consistent approach is available to the various types of prospective applicants for the development allowance.

Where all other criteria in the principal act are met, these amendments would allow the transfer of the Development Allowance benefit where ownership of a project is transferred to another entity after application for the Development Allowance but before registration.

Secondly, the amendments would allow the transfer of the Development Allowance benefit where ownership of a project is transferred from one entity structure to another type of entity structure after application for the Development Allowance.
To maximise the effectiveness of the amendments, they will be retrospective and will apply from 1 January 1993, which is the date applications for the Development Allowance closed.

The amendments will also provide that any applications for registration of plant expenditure that were refused, or granted in respect of an amount of expenditure that was less than the amount of expenditure whose registration was sought in the application, may be granted in full if they would have been granted in full if the amendments proposed in this bill had been in force when the principal act received Royal Assent.

Moreover, the amendments will provide that any application for registration of plant expenditure that was withdrawn, may be taken not to have been withdrawn if an application for transfer of the benefits of the application for registration could have been made if the amendments proposed in this bill had been in force when the principal act received Royal Assent.

The amendments will also grant the Development Allowance Authority (the DAA) a power to determine that an application by an entity for registration of plant expenditure has lapsed in certain limited circumstances.
The opportunity is also taken to make some minor administrative adjustments and to correct certain apparent drafting errors.

The cost to revenue of the proposed amendments is expected to be approximately $10 million per annum. Over the nine years from 1993-94 to 2001-02, the total cost to revenue of the amendments is expected to be approximately $92 million.
This revenue cost relates only to unregistered projects that have already restructured or have developed an intention to restructure before registration.
There is no reliable estimate of the prospective cost of allowing all types of restructuring after registration, but the cost is unlikely to be more than $3 million per annum.

It is arguable whether the additional cost to revenue should be viewed as merely restoring the revenue cost of having the Development Allowance initiative operate with the economic effect that the government originally intended.

AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL

The most important provisions of this bill are aimed against police corruption. Members will be aware that the current Royal Commission into the New South Wales Police Service has uncovered distressing instances of corruption and other serious misconduct. Such abuse of power and of the community's trust can never be tolerated in any police service. The government particularly regrets that serving and former members of the Australian Federal Police have admitted to the Royal Commission their involvement with members of the New South Wales Police Service in corruption and other reprehensible behaviour.

The government and the administration of the Australian Federal Police is strongly committed to ensuring that it is never debilitated by a culture of corruption and misconduct. The institutional culture of a police force is of vital importance to a community. A police force stands at the threshold of the criminal justice system and is in effective control of the enforcement of the criminal law. Each police officer has an extensive authority over all other citizens, coupled with a wide discretion over its exercise. Subsequent stages in the criminal justice process, including courts and prisons, are largely dependent on the activities of police services, and will inevitably be affected by their deficiencies.

The commonwealth is of course particularly dependent on the integrity and efficiency of the Australian Federal Police. First it is the prime agency for the enforcement of the Commonwealth's criminal laws. In this area it is the Australian community's first line of professional defence against crime and disorder. In addition, the Australian Federal Police provides a vital link in effective cooperation with international law enforcement bodies. It is essential that the Australian Federal Police maintain the confidence of these bodies as well as the public's confidence.

In 1989 the government initiated a major and innovative reform of the legislation which governs the Australian Federal Police. The reform was designed in part to introduce a new and unique employment scheme which would inhibit the occurrence of the deep patterns of corruption uncovered in other police services. One aspect of these reforms was the replacement of tenure with a system of fixed term appointments. Another aspect was providing the commissioner with Chief Executive powers in relation to appointments within the Australian Federal Police, including the power to end the appointment of any police member or civilian staff member. One of the principles underlying this employment scheme is that the commissioner should have a clear and specific responsibility for the integrity and operational efficiency of the Australian Federal Police. Naturally, the scheme also envisages that the commissioner should have the powers and authority necessary to fulfil these responsibilities.

At present the commissioner's power to terminate the appointment of members or staff members of the Australian Federal Police is subject only to two exceptions. The current legislation states that the commissioner must not make use of this power merely because of an act by a member or staff member where a disciplinary charge has been or could be laid in relation to that act or merely because a court has convicted or found the individual guilty of a criminal offence.

These exceptions were provided in order to separate the Australian Federal Police's disciplinary processes which can result in dismissal as a penalty for a disciplinary offence from the commissioner's general power to end a person's appointment. In practice, the limitations on the commissioner's dismissal power can lead to situations which are clearly inconsistent with the policy aims of the AFP employment scheme. For example, it is not clear that the commissioner can terminate the appointment of a member of the Australian Federal Police even if the member admits publicly that he or she is guilty of corruption or other serious reprehensible behaviour. To dismiss that person from the Australian Federal Police, it might be necessary for the commissioner either to invite the member to resign voluntarily or to initiate disciplinary proceedings. The commissioner's hands could be equally tied if the person were to be convicted of serious criminal offences by a court.

The government believes this situation to be unsatisfactory. Corruption in a police service can seriously undermine the professional self respect and morale of the decent and honest police who comprise the majority of members. It can also seriously diminish public confidence in the affected police service. Immediate and effective action may be the only way to minimise the harm. On occasions it will not be desirable to wait for lengthy disciplinary or court proceedings to be finally resolved before acting.

Consequently, the bill will remove the present limitations on the commissioner's dismissal powers which relate to disciplinary offences and criminal convictions. The intention is to give the commissioner a broader and more effective power to end an appointment where the commissioner has lost confidence in a person's suitability for the vocation of policing or for continued employment in the Australian Federal Police. The amendment will, in particular, permit the commissioner to act quickly and decisively to end the appointment of a person where the commissioner believes on reasonable grounds that there has been serious corruption, gross abuse of power or serious dereliction of duty.

While the government believes it is necessary in the public interest for the commissioner to have a wide discretion to end appointments, it also recognises that the employment rights of individual members and staff members within the Australian Federal Police should also be protected.

Currently members and staff members are protected in two ways in the event that they are retired by the commissioner before the end of their term of appointment. First, the person who is retired may seek judicial review by the Federal Court of the commissioner's decision to end their appointment. Second, the retired person is entitled to compensation for the lost part of their appointment.

As this bill will widen the scope of the commissioner's powers to end appointments, the government believes it is also reasonable to extend to members and staff members additional remedies against the possibility that the commissioner's power might be exercised unfairly or unreasonably. Consequently, it has been decided that, in addition to the existing protective measures I have outlined, individual members and staff members who have their appointments terminated early will also have access to the remedies against the unlawful termination of employment given to employees in Division 3 of Part VIA of the Industrial Relations Act 1988. At present the Australian Federal Police is excluded from those unlawful termination provisions by the Industrial Relations Regulations. The relevant Regulations will be repealed following the commencement of this bill.

The bill makes one exception to the opening of the unfair dismissal remedies to the Australian Federal Police. It provides that where a person's appointment has been ended because of their conduct or behaviour, the commissioner may make a declaration that the conduct or behaviour amounts to serious misconduct and that the serious misconduct is having, or is likely to have, a damaging effect on professional self-respect or morale within the Australian Federal Police or on its reputation with the public or with an Australian or overseas government or law enforcement agency. Where a declaration of this kind is made, the person who has been retired will be excluded from the operation of the Industrial Relations Act provisions concerning unlawful dismissal. Such persons, however, will retain the present rights to compensation for their early retirement and to seek judicial review of the commissioner's declaration, as well as the decision to end their appointment.

As I have indicated, the commissioner will be able to make a declaration only where the commissioner believes, on reasonable grounds, that there has been serious misconduct by the person who is retired. Serious misconduct is defined to include corruption, a serious abuse of power, a serious dereliction of duty and any other seriously reprehensible act or behaviour. It is also necessary that the commissioner believe that the serious misconduct is actually damaging, or is likely to damage, the Australian Federal Police in one of the ways I have described. This is in line with an agreement between the AFP and the Australian Federal Police Association which provides for the commissioner to exercise this power in cases of serious corruption and gross abuse of power. Further procedures will provide for consultation with the Association in the exercise of the power and for me to receive reports annually on the use of such powers.

Clearly these are special circumstances. They are circumstances in which immediate action by the commissioner is needed to maintain the internal integrity or the public reputation of the Australian Federal Police and where it is not appropriate that an outside tribunal should be able to remake the commissioner's decision.

The amendment will permit the commissioner to make a declaration either before or after the behaviour or conduct in question becomes widely known. This is to allow the commissioner to act to preempt the threatened damage to the morale or reputation of the Australian Federal Police.

I would like to add that the Australian Federal Police Association has endorsed the need for the changes which I have just outlined. On behalf of the government I take this opportunity to congratulate the Association and its members for their strong and consistent commitment to a professional and corruption free Australian Police Force.

The bill also contains several minor amendments concerning two separate matters. One group of amendments is intended to give the Governor-General the power to authorise the commissioner and the Deputy commissioners to appoint or promote persons as commissioned officers with the Australian Federal Police. At present the legislation permits the Governor-General to give this authority only to the commissioner. The new arrangements are administratively more convenient. The amendments allows for appropriate safeguards.

The second group of amendments deals with the disciplinary obligations of staff members when granted special leave of absence for service with an industrial association. The effect is to extend the existing provisions which deal with members to staff members as well.
The amendments have no financial impact.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
