1.1 The Commonwealth Government welcomes the report by the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee on Accountability in Commonwealth-State Funding Arrangements in Education. The report provides a summary of many of the issues and complexities surrounding financial and educational accountability arrangements for the Commonwealth's Schools Programs and has identified a number of key issues in the post-compulsory sector for both the schools and vocational sectors.

1.2 As the report acknowledges, the question of accountability for the Commonwealth's contribution to the funding of Australia's schools is neither a new issue nor a simple one. The number of stakeholders in school education and, in particular, the roles of the Commonwealth and the States and Territories have a major impact on how accountability has developed and how it can be modified in future.

1.3 The Commonwealth Government welcomes the Committee's emphasis on the need to improve the reporting of student outcomes. The lack of such data has been of concern to the Government and was highlighted in the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) submission to the Committee. As detailed in the responses to each of the recommendations in the Committee's report, the Commonwealth is addressing these concerns.

1.4 In formulating this response the Government has had the benefit of advice from a number of key education organisations from both the government and non-government sector. The Commonwealth values the views of these organisations.
Current accountability requirements

2.1 The Commonwealth Government shares the Committee's assumption that the annual National Report on Schooling in Australia (ANR) will continue to be the Commonwealth's chief educational accountability mechanism for its annual expenditure on schooling of more than $3 billion. This reflects the current strengths of the ANR as a reporting mechanism. The Committee has observed (page 24) that `good accountability mechanisms between the States and the Commonwealth should reflect the shared responsibility involved and should entail some form of shared accountability arrangements'. The ANR is such a shared accountability mechanism. It was developed with the co-operation of the States to replace a plethora of separate, disjointed accountability requirements. It serves a number of purposes, enabling the States and the non-government sector to meet their educational accountability to the Commonwealth, it contributes to the Commonwealth Minister's reporting to Parliament and enables all levels of the government and the non-government school sectors to report to the community.

2.2 The Committee has pointed out some weakness of this approach, in particular that the framework for reporting ` is not very prescriptive nor specific in its demand for details ` that it fails `to provide a means of making comparison between States', that there `is certainly little of a critical nature in the material provided' and that `the most important consideration pertaining to the ANR as the Commonwealth's prime accountability document remains its inadequacy with respect to reporting upon educational outcomes'.(pages 34, 36-38).

2.3 In part these aspects of the ANR reflect the fact that it is an agreed mechanism to which all States and non-government authorities must contribute. Many of the Committee's observations will be addressed in the 1995 ANR which will be drafted against a new reporting framework (see Attachment page 24). This framework, based on the new format agreed by State and Territory Ministers for Education in October 1994, includes each of the four focus areas agreed by State and Territory Ministers for Education and the Commonwealth. As Ministers have agreed that the ANR should increasingly include nationally comparable student outcomes data, the Commonwealth will be carefully assessing States' contributions (not due until mid-1996) against this new framework and will consider the need to be more prescriptive in light of that performance.

2.4 The Commonwealth fully endorses the views of the Committee of `the need for the outcomes data to be presented in such a way that will allow for comparability between States, and also over time' with the material `presented in a way that will not encourage comparisons to be made which ignore contextual backgrounds'(page 102). `The Committee believes that it is to the production of this [educational outcomes] data that most efforts should be directed'. (pages 129-131). DEET's submission pointed out that the Commonwealth's major concern with the ANR has been the lack of outcomes data. The Commonwealth has been acting on this concern and initiatives by the Commonwealth in the last two years have included:
development of a new framework for the 1995 and future ANRs, based on agreement by Ministers that future ANRs will increasingly report nationally comparable outcomes data;
negotiation of agreements with States and non-government school authorities for the Commonwealth's new National Equity Program for Schools (NEPS) which include tighter accountability requirements;

development and funding of sample studies (such as those on socioeconomic status, subject choice and non English speaking background) which include definition of outcomes or target groups as specific objectives and funding of related studies (such as the Third International Mathematics and Science Study and an Australian Curriculum Assessment and Certification Authorities (ACACA) study on Year 12 data);
development of the National School English Literacy Survey to produce nationally consistent data on literacy performance; and

grants for Management Information Systems development, in association with the signing of the 1994 NEPS agreements, to enable systems to enhance their data collection methods so that they can report on outcomes as required under NEPS.

2.5 The initiatives set out above are scheduled to conclude in the next 12—18 months. In addition, the first report of the COAG Review of Commonwealth-State Service Standards, which is aimed at predicting outcomes measures applicable to a wide range of government programs, is scheduled to be received from the Industry Commission in December 1995 (see also Response to Recommendation 3 paragraph 3.7)

The Commonwealth is concerned to develop better reporting of educational outcomes, consistent with the COAG agreement that the Commonwealth's interests will be in broadly agreed strategic goals involving program planning and a concern for achieving program performance and outcomes for clients.

2.7 One of the fundamental principles underlying the establishment of the ANR is that the outcomes of schooling cannot be attributed to individual inputs. Accordingly, the ANR concentrates on the overall outcomes of schooling, rather than accounting separately for Commonwealth, State and other inputs.

2.8 The Committee refers to substitution of Commonwealth funds for State funding, citing allegations relating to special purpose programs in Victoria. The issue of substituting Commonwealth for State funds is an ongoing issue of public concern and affects all Commonwealth-State programs, not just those in education. The Committee notes that substitution is difficult to detect and quantify, although suspicion of the practice is widespread (page 55). DEET has no direct evidence concerning substitution of funds for specific programs. There is, however, evidence from State budget documents that, while the Commonwealth is increasing its level of funding for schools, some State Governments are reducing their expenditure and that a de facto substitution of Commonwealth for State effort is taking place. For example, the Victorian Budget for 1995-96 shows a minor decrease in funding of 0.1 per cent for each government school student. Commonwealth funding to Victoria has increased, however, by 1.8 per cent in real terms and, if the Commonwealth's effort is taken out, there has been a real decrease in State expenditure of 0.5 per cent for each student.

2.9 The Commonwealth agrees with the Committee's view (page 57) that making the accountability pathway more transparent will do much to allay suspicions of substitution. refining existing processes such as the ANR and NEPS agreements to place greater emphasis on reporting of educational outcomes (these are described in detail later in the response);
co-operating with the States and Territories and non-government authorities to create data bases on student learning eg National School English Literacy Survey;
considering the findings of the COAG review and of independent studies into educational outcomes; and

considering the implications of the Review of Resource Levels in Government Primary Schools which has examined the level of resources available to government primary schools for literacy development. TALK.START.PARA: —I speak to this motion firstly to congratulate the government on its response to the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee's report into accountability in Commonwealth-state funding arrangements in education. If one considers the report and the government response, one can see that these are issues that the committee has examined in detail and that the government has considered them carefully and, in my view, given a very good response to the committee's considerations.

PARA.TAB: The central issue of this report relates to the Commonwealth-state accountability and in particular the capacity of state governments to undermine the national program educational objectives of the Commonwealth by substituting Commonwealth funds for state funds. These are very important issues in so far as they go to the question of future opportunities for many thousands of Australians, to future opportunities of this country and to the very basic question of the future opportunities in terms of equality that we are, I would hope, all committed to in ensuring that Australians all get a fair go.

The Commonwealth is spending considerable sums of money on its commitment in education, and that commitment is not being met at the state level. This report highlights the discrepancies that exist in both the accounting practices that exist between the states and the Commonwealth, and the fact that the states are not meeting their obligations to the Australian citizens of today and, of course, of tomorrow.

I draw the Senate's attention to the government's response, which highlights the complexities of the issue in terms of tracking substitution at the state level. In particular, I refer to the report where it says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee notes that substitution is difficult to detect and to quantify, although suspicion of the practice is widespread . . . DEET has no direct evidence concerning substitution of funds for specific programs. There is, however, evidence from State budget documents that, while the Commonwealth is increasing its level of funding for schools, some State Governments are reducing their expenditure and that a de facto substitution of Commonwealth for State effort is taking place. For example, the Victorian Budget for 1995-96 shows a minor decrease in the funding of 0.1 per cent for each government school student. The Commonwealth funding to Victoria has increased, however, by 1.8 per cent in real terms and, if the Commonwealth's effort is taken out, there has been a real decrease in State expenditure of 0.5 per cent for each student.

PARA.TAB: Many have said—and it has been put on many occasions by many state premiers—that, because the Commonwealth expends only 10 per cent or 12 per cent of total funding in education, it has no role. The significance of that is that, when you do look at total expenditure by the Commonwealth in education and you add up not just tied grants but untied Commonwealth contributions to everyday running costs and capital outlays of government schools, you find that the effective total Commonwealth contribution of funding per student for government schools is now just under 44 per cent. Recent reports by the government have picked up the evidence contained in this committee's report. So this committee's report is now starting to flow right through government action. For instance, the recent Schools Council's report on Resources and Accountability: Commonwealth Funding Scenarios for Government Primary Schools came to similar conclusions as those which were drawn by the Senate committee itself and which have been picked up by the government in its response here today. There is a growing demand across this country for the Commonwealth to be more involved in education. There is a growing demand for the Commonwealth to ensure that there is equality of opportunity. The whole issue relates to the conditions of funding because it is on that basis that the great doors of inequality will be unlocked. There is a vested interest in making sure that people don't know what is happening to our schools in this country at this time.

We have seen in recent years the Kennett government in Victoria cut school funding by 10 per cent—some $240 million in real terms. The effect of that is something the Liberals in Victoria do not want to be known. They do not want the public to appreciate what the effect of such devastating cuts has been.

In terms of budget outlays on education in Victoria, the percentage of spending has dropped from 26 per cent in 1989-90 to 18 per cent last year. It is a dramatic drop. There is an ideological divide occurring in this country about the importance of education. Of course conservative governments at the state level think too much money is being spent on education. The argument now is that the Commonwealth is doing too much in education and the conservative governments would like to cut that back.

If you exclude the Commonwealth outlays, there has been a six per cent drop in funding in Victoria on a school by school basis. Teacher numbers have fallen by 3,000 in 1993 and a further 2,900 in 1994, and they continue to decline. TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I raise before the Senate in this adjournment debate relates to the inadequate provision of maternal and child health services in Victoria. PARA.TAB: As my fellow senators are aware, I recently had cause to use the maternal and child health services. Historically, in Victoria, the maternal and child health services have played a vital role in ensuring the good health of babies and their mothers with the provision of services such as early identification of problems; prevention of child abuse and postnatal depression; support of breastfeeding and immunisation of babies; establishment of play groups and parents groups; and providing advice, information, family support and referrals to other services.

Unfortunately, under the Kennett coalition government in Victoria, a program called Healthy Futures operates. It partly funds just one component of a true maternal and child health service; that is, developmental monitoring at 10 set stages, with limited funds, for special needs visits—10 visits over 3 1/2 years. This is a child who is not unwell and who spends more than half of his time out of the actual state.

Local government can choose whether it provides more than this minimum service or not. Many councils have chosen not to fund additional maternal and child health services—and this is the type of choice that the coalition talks about. As a consequence, the provision of this service is highly inconsistent right across Victoria. In all areas the changes have restricted access from flexible arrangements depending on need to a rigid quota system which is not able to adequately meet the needs of new mothers. It is inconceivable that new mothers and their babies should have to wait a week to be able to see a maternal and child health nurse for 15 minutes.

Under the Victorian Healthy Futures program, maternal and child health nurses are restricted from seeing mothers less than five days after they have given birth. Yet under the health policies of the Kennett administration, mothers are being pushed out of public hospitals after two or three days. No-one seems to know who has the responsibility for the care and support of new mothers and their babies in the event of a problem presenting on the third or fourth day after the child's birth. No-one seems to know, and the Victorian coalition government certainly seems not to care.

Problems occur out of hours and 10 visits are not adequate. People go to the chemist where unqualified people are expected to give advice. That is the plight of mothers in many areas across the state—having to take advice from unqualified people in the `privacy' of a chemist shop. But there has also been a plethora of pharmacies offering the services of a maternal and child health nurse to their customers. This is coalition policy at its worst; it has led to the corporatisation of a health service provided by the state government which was previously free. But who is there now to ask about the qualifications of these experts in pharmacies who are providing advice? And who is there to provide ongoing care and follow-up where it is necessary?

Kennett style liberalism has taken the maternal out of maternal and child health services and is attempting to downgrade the service into a glorified baby weighing service. Spending on family support services, such as maternal and child health services, should be regarded as an investment in the future wellbeing of children, families and communities, repaying their costs by the prevention of serious and costly health and social problems which will be picked up in the future. Governments must recognise the essential role of families in the love, care and nurturing of babies, and governments must provide support to families in that caring role.

In Victoria the state government has also reduced funding to kindergartens by 20 per cent. Principally because of the lack of ability to pay increased fees, many families now view child care as an acceptable alternative to kindergarten. The Kennett government has unashamedly viewed kindergarten and preschool as an unnecessary adjunct to a four-year-old's life. Many parents, usually on one income, not receiving a health care card, will have to prioritise their child-care costs.

The problems raised with the Child Care Amendment Bill relate to cutbacks in state services and a need for greater flexibility in the provision of child-care services, rather than in any abrogation of responsibility on behalf of the federal government. A few private child-care centres unable to utilise spare capacity have not viewed the 12-hour proposal well.

But after-school care, before-school care and occasional child care are all important times when child care is a necessary component of family wellbeing—and the industry should cater for it. Private child-care centres must be made to adjust to the varied and changing needs of their clients and have flexibility in their administrative arrangements. Parents who choose to utilise the 12-hour limit of subsidised care should be able to have their child in care over three days, if that is what they require, without overpayment and without oversubsidisation by the Commonwealth.

In this chamber we have heard much about the support that families need. TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Panizza formally moved notice of motion No. 1870 concerning the sinking of HMAS Sydney. The sinking of HMAS Sydney on 19 November 1941 has gone down as an unparalleled disaster in Australian naval history. There were no survivors of the 645 officers on board and therefore no-one to tell the tale of the ship's engagement with the disguised German auxiliary raider the Kormoran off the Western Australian coast.

PARA.TAB: Sydney sank virtually without trace. All that remained were a small carly float and two charred lifebelts, while more than 300 Germans were rescued from lifeboats. The mystery remains, though there are a number of theories that explain what happened. The question whether the carly float came from the Sydney is still debated. The body that was washed up on Cocos Islands some months after the disaster may or may not have come from HMAS Sydney. It was a tragedy that cut deep into the national psyche. Sydney was considered invincible and her actions on that fatal day have never fully been explained.

Sydney had a battle inspired history. She had played a leading role in the Mediterranean during May 1940. During her time there, she suffered over 60 air attacks and the Italians claim to have sunk her more than eight times. In July 1940, during the battle of Crete, Sydney sank the Italian cruiser Bartolomeo Colleoni. These were grim days for the allies, with retreats in the desert and the Battle of Britain about to be joined. Sydney's success was a rare flicker of hope. She had the status that we would today give to all our sporting heroes combined.
Sydney was reassigned to the defence of Australia and arrived in Sydney on 9 February 1941. Nine months later she was sunk. Former Navy Minister Billy Hughes remarked:

SPEECH.PARA: This magnificent ship had seemed to have a charmed life. She had run the gauntlet of the toughest battles in the Mediterranean and escaped with not so much more than a scratch on her paint. Everyone of her countrymen had thrilled to her exploits.

As Tom Frame points out in his excellent book on this tragedy—HMAS Sydney Loss and Controversy—the war had certainly come to Australia's doorstep. To be sunk so inexplicably by a sinister German raider was a very great concern. Flags on public buildings in Sydney were flown at half-mast as a mark of respect on the morning of 1 December 1941. The city had lost its flagship. The loss was made even worse from the point of view that six days later, on 7 December 1941, the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbour.

PARA.TAB: The Lord Mayor of Sydney, Alderman Stanley Crick, said that the city had suffered the greatest heartache in its history. An HMAS Sydney replacement fund was launched in every capital city. Tom Frame observed that apart from the little that the German survivors could recall or were willing to disclose, the reasons behind her final and inexplicable movements and the disappearance of the ship and her men were destined to remain, and have remained, a mystery.

Despite detailed research carried out in Australia, Britain, the United States and Germany, the absence of a single survivor from Sydney to describe the action through Australian eyes means that the prospects of solving the mystery will always be limited. Tom Frame further observed that since its foundation in 1911, the Royal Australian Navy has quickly learned from its mistakes. That no other ship was lost in similar circumstances to Sydney during the war suggests that the navy learned all there was to learn from her loss. But despite all the theories of what happened, there is still a large question mark about her loss.

This country owes the surviving family members of those who lost their lives on HMAS Sydney the consideration of a full-scale public search for the vessel and the erection of a memorial in Canberra, as Senator Panizza calls for in his motion. I understand it will not be easy to locate the wreck because the area that will have to be searched is very large. I heard a naval salvage expert say recently that anything over 100 square kilometres was very difficult and very expensive with present technology, but he suggested that in time that will change.

I also fully support Senator Panizza's suggestion that the government approach the British government to lift its 70-year moratorium on releasing its war file on the sinking of HMAS Sydney so that we may know more of the facts and circumstances surrounding the sinking of the Sydney, because undoubtedly there are some other theories that can be put to the test.I add my support to Senator Panizza's motion. It was a very great loss to Australia in a very dark period in our history and it would be very important to know a little more about what happened. Certainly, we could mark it with a proper memorial.

In addition to this, in the election of Divisional Conference Delegates he published a result that was not in conformity with the count in any event. In this instance he published a result that not only did not include the disputed members as elected but also excluded one of the elected office bearers, one Tony Ricciardo whose eligibility was not in question. This meant that there were two additional individual members elected to be delegates to Divisional Conference. Ricciardo was already to be a delegate as he had been previously elected as a Divisional Council delegate which gave him voting rights at the Divisional Conference. Had Ricciardo been elected to two positions entitling him to vote at Divisional Conference (as in fact was the case) he would notwithstanding only have had one vote as delegates are not entitled to multiple voting rights at Divisional Conferences [see Constitution Clause 137(k)(ii)].

Should Mr Filing seek to maintain that he removed Mr Ricciardo upon the basis that he was already a Divisional Council delegate—this does not ring true as the member who moved up the ladder to fill the fifth delegates position was Mr John Rice who had also been elected as a Divisional Vice President and was already entitled to vote at Divisional Conference and on such an analysis should also have been removed. Effectively what appears to have transpired is a "pickled vote" as delivered by Mr Filing to the Branch President and the Divisional Secretary. The proposition is that Rice, already being an elected delegate to Divisional Conference would not have had a vote as number five delegate of the Branch to Divisional Conference. All of this occurred one week prior to Divisional Conference for the Moore Division.

Mr Filing's electoral officer, Reva Evans personally delivered the "pickled" result to the Divisional Secretary on the 3rd of October at approximately 7.30pm. The Divisional Conference was scheduled and duly held on the 11th of October 1994.
On the 4th of October 1994 the other scrutineer, Mr Ron Privilege attended at Head Office and observed the State Director count the votes.

The Divisional Secretary had by the 4th of October 1994 confirmed with the State Director that there were two results but as there had been no official complaint the three disputed members were eligible.

At the Moore Divisional Conference Mr Filing objected to Mr Darby-Smith, Mr Greenhow and Mr Cook voting. It was explained to him that there had been no official complaint as to the Joondalup Branch elections and Mr Filing responded that there would be. The State Director had prior to the commencement of the Divisional Conference informed the Divisional Secretary that there was no problem with respect to the accreditation of the three disputed members.

The Divisional Secretary advised Head Office as to her understanding of who was accredited during the afternoon prior to the meeting and did not receive any advice to the contrary other than orally from the State Director as stated, to confirm that the three disputed members were eligible.
On the 24th of October 1994 the State Director wrote to Mr Filing seeking an explanation as to these events. By letter dated the 28th of October 1994 Mr Filing confirmed as follows:
"Thank you for your letter of 24th October 1994 concerning the count of the Joondalup Branch AGM.
I have enclosed, as requested, a copy of the list compiled for and on behalf of the Joondalup Branch President and at his request delivered to the Divisional Secretary.
This list is based on the count for positions, excluding the disputed members. The list was the same as the hand written one copied and retained by you.
If I can be of any further assistance, please let me know."
The second sentence in the penultimate paragraph is incorrect as set out above in that Ricciardo's name had been deleted from the list of Divisional Conference Delegates.
Action
It is suggested that the State President put these matters to Mr Filing and request that he attend State Executive and answer the issues.

That means absolutely nothing to anybody who does not understand the machinations of the Liberal Party of Western Australia. It was that document that caused me to ring the leadership of the Liberal Party when I was asked to make sure that no motion against Mr Filing was moved for his suspension, censure or expulsion. I made it quite clear to the leadership that I was gravely concerned about the prospect that anything of an improper nature should proceed through the state executive with my approval.

PARA.TAB: As events transpired, I managed to negotiate Mr Filing through state executive without a motion of any sort. Mr Filing had the audacity yesterday to provoke me to make those comments. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 27 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Trans-Tasman Treaty with New Zealand, under which all trade between Australia and New Zealand is supposedly free of barriers, and to the fact that under Section 20 of the Therapeutic Goods Act, the sale of pharmaceuticals approved for sale in Australia is restricted in New Zealand, as it is considered an export:
(1) Was this an intention of the Act.
(2) Is there any consideration being given by the Government to correcting this anomaly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Section 20 of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 (the Act) is not inconsistent with the Australia New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement (ANZCERTA).

Article 18 of ANZCERTA provides for member states to adopt measures to protect human, animal and plant life or health. Section 20 of the Act, preventing import or export of therapeutic goods for use in humans unless the goods are registered, listed, exempt or approved, is clearly a measure designed to protect human health and is therefore a valid measure under Article 18. Section 20 operates to regulate imports and exports for valid public health reasons. It does not prohibit imports and exports in an arbitrary or unjustified manner.
In any event, ANZCERTA does not operate to override existing Australian domestic legislation.
(2) Section 20 of the Act is consistent with Australia's international legal obligations.
